passages.text: China (PRC) | Home Appliances Midea Group

Midea management continues to highlight demand uncertainties (earnings call at Aug- 29 after HK market close). However, we view Midea better positioned vs. peers due to (1) Defensive US & EU strategies, (2) Market share capture from Gree and (3) Turnaround in Capital goods business. We are concerned about global appliances demand, but expect Midea to guard and compound investor capital. With a \(13\%\) 2026E FCF yield and increasing payout & buyback, we remain Buy.

Defensive strategies in the US and EU. Our case study of the 2018- 2023 US washing machine tariff (see below section) shows risks ahead including: (1) US demand may temporarily surge ahead of tariff then subsequently collapse with significant inflation, and (2) EU price competition may intensify.

We believe Midea is managing the risks well considering that (1) its US revenue exposure is less than \(5\%\) (2) its products are positioned as value- for- money in the EU, (3) it is not building new capacity in the US amid the temporary demand surge.

AC (air conditioners): Midea is likely the best positioned to benefit from Gree's continued market share loss. We believe Gree's off- line channel is deteriorating (see note). We estimate that most AC brands in China will take market share from Gree, with Midea to benefit the most, given: (1) Cost advantage: Midea has one of the most competitive cost structures among global split- type AC makers, thanks to strong vertical integration; (2) Midea has a full range of products that could absorb consumer demand from Gree; and (3) Midea has one of the most efficient retail networks in China. Midea has largely completed its digital and DTC transformation.
If we assume Gree loses \(60\%\) of its AC revenue in the next 5 years and \(80\%\) of that revenue goes to Midea, this would boost Midea's total revenue by \(17\%\) (Chart 1).

Capital goods business. Midea's investments to enhance its capital goods business (mainly robotic and heat management) have been dragging FCF generation, in our view. However, we believe the investments have started to bear fruit since 2H24. We note that the Chinese government is resuming infrastructure projects and focus on advanced technologies (for instance, robotics). We also note that, during economic downturns, the government may provide more support to the aforementioned sectors. This would help Midea sustain its growth even after the appliances trade- in stimulus starts to fade.

FCF yield \(3\%\) , buyback, dividend. Midea's shares offer good investment value, in our view, given (1) Solid cash flow compounding: 1H25 FCF increased by \(15\%\) YoY. In 2022, Midea's FCF was RMB27bn; we expect 2025 to reach more than RMB60bn. We estimate Midea's shares are trading at \(11\% /13\%\) FCF yield in 2025/26. (2) We expect Midea to consistently increase output and introduce more buybacks. We update our model and increase DCF- based PTs to reflect Midea's strong FCF generation.

Please see analyst certifications, important disclosure information, and information regarding the status of non-Us analysts on pages 5 - 11 of this report. \\* Jefferies Hong Kong Limited
We believe Midea's equity story is the creation of sustainable value for investors (beyond property and monetary cycles) via strong execution and reforms.

Relative to consensus, we are more positive on the benefits from Midea's channel reforms. We believe the new organization and channel structure position Midea well amid a slowing property market. We are also more positive on Midea's ability to fend off, and even counter, competition, in the air conditioner industry. Last, but not least, we are more positive on KUKA's improving fundamentals (both cyclical and structural).
Risk/Reward - 12 Month View

- Split-type AC: Midea gains some market share with healthy distributor cash flow.- Emerging channels: the new channels progress in line with management's plans.- KUKA: gradual recovery from a global demand shock.- Further efficiency gains are realized, thanks to better monitoring of supply chain and distribution data.- Price target of RMB98 (HKD108), based on DCF.

- Split-type AC: Midea gains significant market share with healthy distributor cash flow.- Emerging channels: the new channels progress better than management's plans.- KUKA: sales growth, with improving profitability.- Further efficiency gains are realized, thanks to better monitoring of supply chain and distribution data.- Price target of RMB130 (HKD143), based on DCF.

- Split-type AC: Midea loses market share but maintains largely healthy distributor cash flow.- Emerging channels: the new channels progress worse than management's plans.- KUKA: sales and profitability decline.- Limited efficiency gains realized, as Midea's initiatives fail to drive efficiency gains.- Price target of RMB60 (HKD66), based on DCF.

Top Material Issue(s): Product- Safety and Environmental Protection are the main concerns for the home appliance industry. We observe that Midea has implemented safety management mechanism and global compliance control methods to ensure product safety. Regarding lowering carbon emissions, Midea has adopted a six- pillar approach 'green design, green purchase, green manufacturing, green logistics, green recycling, green services' to achieve its emissions reduction goal.
Company Target(s): "3060" strategy: aims for carbon peak by 2030 and to achieve carbon neutrality by 2060.
Qsto Mgmt: 1) How are your green products received by the market? 2) How is the demand for green products different in overseas and domestic markets?

- Midea's financial statements demonstrate better quality than its key competitor's (quality in terms of cash flow and balance sheet).- Third-party industry data show Midea's market share gain in both split-type and central AC industries.- Capital management programs that reward investors.
Case study of the 2018- 2023 washing machine tariff
Below is an expert from our Haier report:
\\*US: Case study of the 2018- 2023 washing machine tariff. In 2018- Feb, US government imposed \(>20\%\) import tariff on washers from nearly all the source countries.

(1) Significant demand pull forward, causing a temporary surge in demand. According to academic research (Aaron Flaae, Ali Hortacsu, and Felix Tintelnot, 2020), US import of washing machine surged ahead of the tariff. We also witnessed significant consumer buying ahead of the tariff. This actually caused demand to prosper temporarily, before things collapsed in 2H18.

(2) Price inflation. Flaae, Hortacsu, and Tintelnot's 2020 study estimates the \(>20\%\) tariff eventually resulted in washer prices increasing by nearly \(12\%\) . The scholars also found out that the price of dryers (not subject to tariffs) increased by an equivalent amount.

\\*EU: Collateral damage from US washing machine tariff. US' 2018- 23 washer tariff may have led to more intense competition in the EU washer market, per our observations. We recall the Korean brands launching plans to expand their market share in the EU. Interestingly, Electrolux, whose share price outperformed the OMX in 2017, started its painful under-performance since 2018- Mar.
Below is an expert from our Gree report:

Our checks continue to suggest that the number of Gree's off- line POS (point of sales, stores, e- commerce pickup points...etc.) continues to shrink. Gree's distributors invested in significant inventory in summer 2024, in anticipation of the trade- in stimulus. However, 2024 stimulus started late in August, missing the air conditioner peak season. A lot of Gree distributors hence faced excessive inventory. The excessive inventory slowed distributors' cash conversion cycle.

We note that Gree requires distributors to pay significant upfront (cash) as distributors prepare inventory. We believe a majority of Gree's distributors borrowed money to pay for the upfront. The slower cash conversion cycle hence drove some distributors out of business, causing store shutdowns.

Gree, YTD, has been recruiting new distributors under the brand "Dong's Healthy Home". However, our checks continue to suggest it is difficult to recruit new distributors due to Gree's track record and slowing trade- in stimulus.

We would like to thank Zhaochen Zhang, employee of Evaluerserve Inc., for providing research support services to our preparation of this report.

Midea GroupMidea Group is a leading technology- driven global provider of Smart Home Solutions and Commercial & Industrial Solutions. Under Smart Home Solutions, they offer a wide range of home appliances for consumers; under Commercial & Industrial Solutions, their offerings cover various solutions for enterprise clients. As a Fortune Global 500 company for nine consecutive years, they operate a global business that reaches over 200 countries and regions, with 33 R&D centers, 43 major manufacturing bases and over 190,000 employees across different continents.

We use DCF methodology as our primary approach to value Midea shares, as we expect investors to focus on the company's long- term value creation. In our DCF model, we apply a WACC of \(8.45\%\) , with cost of equity of \(9.50\%\) , risk- free rate of \(3.9\%\) , equity risk premium of \(5.6\%\) , and beta of 1.0. We assume a perpetual growth rate of \(1.0\%\) , in line with our Hong Kong and China consumer sector at \(0.2\%\) .

Key downside risks include: (1) weak execution in global expansion for both KUKA and home appliances; (2) unfavorable raw material costs and FX hurt Midea's profitability; (3) weaker- than- expected distributor health hits Midea's working capital and sales; (4) deteriorating loan quality in Midea's loan book impacts the company's earnings; and (5) significant tightening of property policy by the Chinese government negatively affects Midea's channel conditions.

Our primary valuation methodology is DCF. As most of Gree's business comes from China, we use a \(9.5\%\) China COE, beta of 1.0, and a long- term growth rate of \(1.0\%\) , in line with our \(0.2\%\) sector assumption for other consumer stocks that we cover.

Upside risks include: (1) very heavy governmental support of the property sector; (2) better- than- expected balance sheets at Gree's distributors; (3) Gree's channel reform is successful in integrating online and offline, while reducing price cannibalization; (4) favorable raw material cost environment.

We value Haier Smart Home using a DCF approach as we expect investors to focus on the long- term growth profile. We assume a \(9.5\%\) cost of equity, risk- free rate of \(3.9\%\) , equity risk premium of \(5.6\%\) , and beta of 1.0. We assume a perpetual growth rate of \(1.0\%\) , in line with our Hong Kong and China consumer sector at \(0.2\%\) .

Key downside risks: (1) weaker market share expansion in the EU that hinders revenue growth; (2) greater Sino- US trade tensions, affecting both revenue and profitability; (3) unfavorable FX rates; and (4) unfavorable raw material prices. Key upside risks: (1) better management execution and efficiency gains; (2) strong market share gain in the premium appliances segments globally; (3) favorable FX rates; (4) more favorable policies by the US and the Chinese government.

(Article 3(1)e and Article 7 of MAR) Recommendation Published Recommendation Distributed

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) is \(20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus \(20\%\) or less within a 12- month period.
NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a \(15\%\) stop loss, and the remainder will have a \(20\%\) stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
